div.p:
I trust you will not
think my interference
troublesome but I cannot help saying that for
your sake and for William & the public's I wish
that your letter to Mr. Croker were published-
and I request you will tell me whether
suppos
ing supposing Mr Croker you would have any objection to
it being published if Mr. Croker wished it as much
as I do- Maria Edgeworth

My dear Francis
I am glad that I have received the copy
of your letter to Mr Croker, before my fathers
return home, that I might have it in my
power to write to you, before I hear the opinions
of the higher Powers. I must say if you will
allow of your servants praise, that I think the
letter most clear, modest, yet manly and dis-
interested disinterested . And the arguments, for combining
the Coast with the interior survey of this kingdom,
unanswerable. And much as it thwarts my
interest or rather my ambition, yet I must ac-
-knowledge acknowledge that the military surveyors, are the
proper body to be employed.

However, I think if it was suggested to, Mudge
that two active companies might be formed
out of the present body, now employed in
Scotland, that he or rather government, would
catch eagerly at the idea, for all they want
are situations in which they can place the un-
employed unemployed officers, without the appearance of
jobbing. And it is clear that an accurate
Survey of Ireland, is called for on all sides
By the Admiralty, the military and by
the new grand Jury bill.

As to instruments the expense of an entire
new set is a trifle compared to the expense
of the whole work, And in the next theodolite
they will improve upon the last.

No time need be lost, for I am sure they have
instruments sufficient, for selecting their stations
and laying out the ground for their base
lines. It is wonderful since Gen. Roy's time
and with all the experience that they have had,
if two men are not to be found under Mudge
Who are capable of carrying on separately, a
distinct survey. The cumulation that will
necessarily be exited will be advantageous to
both companies, and to the survey of the two
countries. Then we shall have a chance of their
attempting some improvements.
The Ed.Edinburgh reviewReview will drive them to something new
in the Scotch mountains. I do not in this plan
look forward to being employed under this new
Corps, because without I was well paid it would
lead me entirely into one branch of my profession

This is what you said originally about my being
employment with you. And now I must
tell you that I am as little disappointed as
the of a philosopher and not of a Genius
ought to be. And the chief cause of any sorrow
that I may feel, is from my not being likely to
see you, busy in Ireland. I fear that I
shall be long enough tied here, from various
disappointments, Roscommon maps can not be finished
for two years more. Most fortunately the three
months that you so promptly allowed me, induced Major Taylor
to have my name put in the EngineersEngineer's warrant
from the Post MastersMaster's General, for laying out two
new lines of road chiefly thro' Roscommon and
Longford. This work, will not take up the whole
of the summer, and as the Engineer is paid
2 Gs. a mile, it will just support me till I
have finished the drawing of Roscommon. Can you
find out for me as this young drawer, who would look
forward like myself to good payment by his advance-
-ment advancement in life? All I want is a boy who can draw
neat lines, I will give from 5 to 10 shillings a day.

Now my dear Francis let me thank you, and with just
The same feelings of Gratitude, as if we were first beginning
work together. Thank you for the Fatherly determination
with which you have managed my interests, and tho' I am
not to be employed, I am convinced, that the manner in
which you combined my employment, with yours, must
have been of the highest service to me in London. And I
have myself received proofs of a friendship, that I know not
how I have earned but I hope I may
always deserve to profess.
div.closer:
I am
Your most affectionate
W Edgeworth
